court: Local court (with Change de Nancy appellate review)

formal_accuser.name: Demenge Olry
formal_accuser.relationship_to_accused: claimed to have known her for 10 years; accused her of causing his son's death

accused.name: Claudon Charniere
accused.spouse_name: François Picquot (also called François le Clerc)

witnesses.name: Jehan Andreu
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbour for 14 years, lived two houses away; employed by accused and her husband to work in vines

witnesses.name: Claudon des Clochettes
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: close neighbour for more than 30 years

witnesses.name: Jehan Guillegot
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: close neighbour for 15 years, worked for her and husband, ate with them

harms_alleged.target_relationship: hearsay - did not know who said this

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Claudon Charniere (had frightening vision of Claudon with strange figure)

testimony.quarrel_subject: woman from Warangeville asked for alms and was refused

harms_alleged.attributed_to: woman from Warangeville (according to Claudon's diagnosis)
Claudon Charniere (said it was mal donné but pilgrimages failed)

witnesses.name: Nicolas Foural
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: client; had known her only 2-3 months

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Claudon Charniere (implied - child died despite her pilgrimages)

witnesses.name: Didier Phelipe
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: client/consulter; from same town as her birthplace

harms_alleged.attributed_to: Claudon Charniere (she told him he was 'engenoiché' - bewitched)

timeline.subject: Demenge Olry
timeline.details: Initial statement made at Rosieres accusing Claudon Charniere of causing his son's death; claimed to have known she was a witch for 10 years; threatened to have her burned

timeline.subject: Claudon Charniere
timeline.details: First interrogation; gave biographical information, admitted to healing practices using garter divination; confronted with Demenge Olry who affirmed accusation under oath

timeline.subject: François Picquot (husband)
timeline.details: Husband interrogated about his wife's healing practices

timeline.subject: Claudon Charniere
timeline.details: Change de Nancy asks for further investigation and questions to be asked of Demenge Olry about accusations made at end of his trial

timeline.subject: Claudon Charniere
timeline.details: 14 witnesses interrogated; mostly neighbors and clients; many had heard reputation as witch but saw no harm; several testified about failed healing attempts

timeline.subject: Claudon Charniere
timeline.details: Confronted with select witnesses; denied details from Didier Phelipe; admitted depositions from Rose femme Claudon Chartier, Mengette femme Joseph Guillemin, and Nicolas Foural were true

timeline.subject: François Picquot (husband)
timeline.details: Husband admonished for allowing wife to undertake healing for money; ordered to avoid this in future and pay costs

timeline.subject: Claudon Charniere
timeline.details: Change de Nancy rules she has not been sufficiently charged to be pursued as witch; should be released but strictly forbidden to use garter under threat of corporal punishment

timeline.subject: Claudon Charniere
timeline.details: Local court confirms release but requires payment of trial and imprisonment costs due to confessions about 'abus et superstitions'

prior_accusations.accuser_location: bourgeois of St Dié, resident at Rosieres
prior_accusations.context: Claimed to have known she was a witch for 10 years; named her at end of his own witch trial

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Olry
notable_quotes.french: Que il auroit heu son fils, dernierement mort, duquel il estoit en doeul et amertume et que scavoit estez par le mal a luy donnez par une sorciere demeurant a St Nicolas, nommée la Picatte, laient trouvez par ces jours dernieres par les chemins en presence de gens notables et luy disoit qu'il la feroit brusler ad quoy elle s'en fuait et absentat.
notable_quotes.english: That he had had his son, recently dead, for whom he was in grief and bitterness, and that he knew it was from the harm given to him by a witch living at St Nicolas, named la Picatte, having found her in recent days on the roads in the presence of notable people, and he told her that he would have her burned, at which she fled and absented herself.

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Charniere (to Nicolas Foural's wife)
notable_quotes.french: que si elle avoit suspition sur quelques uns qui auroit donné le mal a son enffant qu'il le voist appeller et que peult estre dieu les ayderoit
notable_quotes.english: that if she had suspicion of anyone who had given the harm to her child, that she should go call on them, and that perhaps God would help them
notable_quotes.context: Advice given regarding illness of Nicolas Foural's son

notable_quotes.speaker: Rose femme Claudon Cordier (reporting Claudon's words)
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoit mal donné par maulvaise gens et si elle se magynoit poinct qui scavoit faict
notable_quotes.english: that it was harm given by evil people and if she could imagine who had done it
notable_quotes.context: Claudon's diagnosis when Rose fell suddenly ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Interrogator (to Claudon)
notable_quotes.french: si elle ne sceit bien qu'elle faict mal d'user de telle charmes enchantement et superstition de la jartiere qu'elle use et que c'est pour abuser tromper et attraper les deniers des paouvres personnes qui s'adresse a elle. Et que les curez excommunient tous les dimenches tous sorciers et sorcieres, devins et devineresses et tous ceulx qu'ilz usent des charmes et contrevenant contre l'honneur de dieu.
notable_quotes.english: if she does not know well that she does wrong to use such charms, enchantment and superstition of the garter that she uses, and that it is to abuse, trick and trap the money of poor people who address themselves to her. And that the priests excommunicate every Sunday all sorcerers and witches, diviners male and female, and all those who use charms and act against the honor of God.
notable_quotes.context: Interrogation challenge about her healing practices, 27 October 1572

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Charniere (response)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle n'en scait rien et qu'elle n'y pense aucun mal non plus qu'il seroit de sa teste
notable_quotes.english: that she knows nothing about it and that she thinks no more evil of it than would be in her head
notable_quotes.context: Her response to accusations that her practices were wrong

relationships.evidence_text: femme François Picquet; married 11 and a half years earlier
Then married Martin Picquot; Husband had died 12 years earlier
Said she had learned her practices from one Thoussaince of Flainville, who was now dead
Witness 6 identified as femme Jehan Andreu
she and her husband had often employed him to work in vines
had worked for her and husband and eaten with them
his small son, who was ill; child finally died

economic_context.details: Accused engaged in healing for payment ('de ses journées, peines et labeurs' - for her days, pains and labors). Required to pay costs of trial and imprisonment. Husband worked as carter. She had worked as servant in youth at various masters. Evidence suggests modest economic status - took payment for healing services, worked in service, no mention of property ownership.

harms_catalog.victim_name: husband of Ragonne femme Remy Tixerand
harms_catalog.harm_description: all swollen, very ill, died soon after Claudon's pilgrimage
harms_catalog.method_alleged: mal St Quentin et St Denis (illness attributed to saints)

harms_catalog.harm_description: swelling; pilgrimages were expensive and did no good
harms_catalog.method_alleged: mal donné; should make pilgrimages to Bel Bernard, St Quentin, St Denis

harms_catalog.harm_description: falling sickness; had frightening vision/fantasye of Claudon with strange figure lacking arms and legs speaking to her
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: feared Claudon because she had given her nothing for costs of journey
harms_catalog.method_alleged: maladye de sainct from St George, St Chrestaille, St Martin

harms_catalog.harm_description: suddenly ill, fell down; pilgrimages did not cure her
harms_catalog.attributed_to: woman from Warangeville (according to Claudon's diagnosis) who asked for alms and was refused
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: woman from Warangeville asked for alms in morning and was refused
harms_catalog.method_alleged: mal donné par maulvaise gens; mal de St Pian, du bel Bernard et de St Denis

harms_catalog.harm_description: ill; pilgrimages by husband did not work; told only she herself making pilgrimages would cure her
harms_catalog.method_alleged: mal donné; same 3 saints (St Pian, Bel Bernard, St Denis)

harms_catalog.harm_description: ill child who died despite pilgrimages
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Claudon Charniere (implied - she was called too late)
harms_catalog.method_alleged: mal donné; first said mal de St Denis, later changed to bel Bernard, St Maurien, and St Pian

harms_catalog.harm_description: engenoiché (bewitched); still ill after pilgrimages; had received last rites
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Claudon Charniere (told him he was bewitched)
harms_catalog.method_alleged: engenoiché; illness from bel Bernard, St Pian, St Remy and St Barthelemeu de Belchamps; said if given on right side as well as left he would have died

material_culture.context: Primary divination tool used by Claudon to diagnose illnesses and identify which saints were responsible; manipulated length of her arm with garter to find the saint
Sent as offerings to saints; burned at shrines; Claudon interpreted how candles burned to predict patient outcomes

material_culture.object: candlewax the size of the child
material_culture.context: Nicolas Foural gave this as offering for his ill son
One of husband's shirts sent with money and candles as offerings during pilgrimage
Sent as offerings to saints; Claudon paid 'de ses journées, peines et labeurs' for her healing services
Brought back from Bel Bernard shrine; Rose veuve Jehan Bourelle drank it for 9 days, made her vomit and she recovered

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; where accused lived and practiced healing
Where initial accusation statement was made by Demenge Olry in house of Jacques de Luppi
Where Demenge Olry was bourgeois; Claudon lived there for 20 years before returning to St Nicolas
Birthplace of Claudon Charniere; home of witness Didier Phelipe
Where Claudon spent 10 years with one master as servant in youth
Where Claudon spent 4.5 years with two masters; home of Thoussaince who taught her garter practices
Native village of first husband Martin Picquot; lived there 2 years
Where Claudon lived before moving to St Nicolas
Location of Bel Bernard shrine for pilgrimages
Location of St Pian shrine for pilgrimages
Home of woman who asked Rose for alms and was refused; woman was 'mal famée' (of bad reputation)

economic_hardship_indicators: Payment for healing services suggests need for income
Witness described pilgrimage expenses as burdensome
Reference to 'deniers des paouvres personnes' (money of poor people)
Woman from Warangeville begging for alms
Accused worked as servant in youth
Required to pay trial and imprisonment costs
religious_calendar_references: St Jean (feast day mentioned as temporal marker)
Sunday masses where priests excommunicate sorcerers

officials_named.name: Nicolas Foural
officials_named.location: Rosieres (received initial accusation statement; also witness 13)

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Both Claudon and Demenge Olry were in prison during interrogation; costs of imprisonment charged to both Claudon and her husband

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Ruled she had not been sufficiently charged to be pursued as witch; should be released but strictly forbidden to use garter in future under threat of corporal punishment

hearsay_chains.content: heard that she had caused deaths of animals but did not know who had said this
heard that in youth she had been 'ung peu desbauchée de son corps' (a bit debauched in her body)

emotional_state_notes: denied charge vigorously when confronted with Demenge Olry

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Denied all details in Didier Phelipe's story; claimed to have said nothing about bewitchment or difficulty

third_parties.relationship_to_accused: identified by Claudon as source of bewitchment

third_parties.name: Joseph Guillemin

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an unusual case - not a typical witch trial leading to execution, but rather a trial focused on unauthorized healing practices using garter divination. The accused was released after Change de Nancy ruled evidence insufficient. Key uncertainties: (1) The exact relationship between François Picquot and François le Clerc - text suggests they may be the same person or Claudon remarried, but '11 and a half years' marriage to Picquot and 12 years since first husband's death suggests François Picquot is her second husband, possibly also known as François le Clerc. (2) Several place names are uncertain (Loupole, Vielle marked with '?' in source). (3) The trial reveals extensive evidence of Claudon's healing practice network - she made pilgrimages for at least 4 named clients and was consulted by many of the witnesses. (4) Most testimony is ambivalent - witnesses heard she was a witch but saw no harm, or consulted her for healing but it failed. (5) The formal accuser, Demenge Olry, was himself imprisoned for witchcraft and named Claudon at the end of his own trial. (6) Economic status assessed as 'poor' based on: need to take payment for healing work, worked as servant in youth, no property mentioned, required to pay trial costs which suggests modest means but not destitute.
